The Barnstormers' Initial offering, William Pratt's temperance farce, "Ten Nights in a
Barroom," will go before the
boards tonight with an all freshMan cast and free admission at
8:30 in the Barn.
While the freshmen, under the
co-direction of George Edmonds
and Dave Scribner, have been rehearsing their burlesqued version
of the play, two appointments
have been made to the Barnstormers' Board of Control and
a new play-directing contest has
been started, according to president Gordon Stick.
Dave Hochberg replaces Kent
Lindquist who resigned, as vicepresident of the dramatic group,
While Dave Scribner takes over

Rogers.
Directing Contest
Under the new play directing
contest, any student who would
like to direct a one act play will
assemble a cast for a script
Which he will select and rehearse

and then present the play before
three judges in the Barn.
A limit of three productions is
allowed, and three people have
already stated desires to be in
the contest, Stick reports. A
prize will be awarded to the
winning director, and participation in the productions will be
for Barnstormer credits. Actors
must not be members of the
dramatic group, and can be from
outside the University, if the
director desires.
The contest will be more fully
explained in the weeks immediately following final examinations for this term, Stick added.
Good Talent
"There seems to be some good
talent in the freshman class,"
Stick stated regarding the forthcoming play, which he expects
will be "a very happy farce."
Warren Donahue, Gerald Le
Roux, John Katz, John Petillo
and Dick Danziger take leading
roles in "Ten Nights in a Barroom," while Andy Thomas, Bill
Bebner, Michael Reisman and
Jim Ransey hold secondary
roles.

Ford Foundation
Grants $805,000
For JHU Profs
The Ford Foundation has
made two Grants totalling $805,000 to the Johns Hopkins University in June of this year for
use in advancing the academic
program here.
Hopkins received $290,000 under
Ford's
Accomplishment
Grant program, which is giving
$50 million to 126 private degree-granting colleges and universities. The University also received $515,000 under the Endowment Grant program. The
Ford Foundation i giving $210
million under this program to
630 private institutions.
According to Mr. Henry S.
Baker, University Treasurer and

assistant professors in the Faculty of Philosophy . and the

full amounts of the Grants are

George Kennan To Talk
On Suez Canal Seizure
George Frost Kennan, former
United States ambassador to the
Soviet Union, will speak on "Long
Term Implications of the Suez
Crisis" as the George Huntington Williams Memorial lecturer
Wednesday, October 17, at the
Johns Hopkins University Shriver
Hall at 8:30 p.m.
Kennan represented the United
States as Ambassador to the Soviet Union in 1952, and since has
been with the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, New
Jersey. He had been associated
with the Institute prior to his
duty in Russia from 195G to 1952.
In diplomatic work since 1927
when he became vice consul in
Hamburg, Germany, Kerman is
the author of "Realities of American Foreign Policy" and "American Diplomacy 1900-195a."
He has served in diplomatic

posts at Tallinn, Riga, Kovno,
and Moscow in Russia since 1928,
as well as in Berlin, Vienna,
Prague, Lisbon and London. He
served as second and first secretary in the U. S. Embassy in
Berlin in 1939 and 1940 at the
beginning of World War II, and
acted as counsellor to the American delegation of the European
Advisory Commission in London
in 1944.
Kennan served as ministercounselor in Moscow in 1945 and
was deputy for Foreign Affairs
for The National War College, in
Washington in 1946. The following year he was appointed as a
member of the policy planning
staff, Department of State, and
became deputy counsellor and
chief long •range advisor to the
Secretary of State in 1949, a
post which he held through 1950.

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

After last Saturday's barren sports agenda on the
Homewood campus, all of the Hopkins intercollegiate fall
sports teams swing into action at home tomorrow.
The Blue Jay soccer squad will be making its initial
regularly scheduled game appearance at Homewood
against usually strong Towson Teachers at noon on the
lower field. This game will mark Jerry Williamson's first
appearance here as the varsity soccer coach. The new Jay
mentor was a former Blue Jay star athlete. It is good to
see that Hopkins men who have interest in coaching can
find a position on the Homewood campus.
Swinging into action tomorrow in their season's 'inaugural, the Hopkins cross country squad will face their
neighborhood rivals, Loyola. The finish of this race will
be one of the features of the half time show of the Hopkins-Hampton-Sydney football game. The cross country
squad often suffers from lack of interest, but the squad
members work earnestly to improve and deserve a cheer
tomorrow whether they win, lose or draw.
Football As Feature

The unquestioned feature of tomorrow's program
however, remains the gridiron clash between the Blue Jays
and Hampton-Sydney. It will be the Mason-Dixon inaugural for both squads.
The Jays have perhaps their strongest starting team
in a number of years but the lack of depth has hurt the
Blue Birds in their first two games. However, the play of
the Jays in these games shows a definite improvement over
last year when they bowed to F&M by one touchdown and
to Carnegie Tech, 26-6.
Whether they have improved enough to defeat the
Southerners, a perennial M-D title contender, is to be answered tomorrow afternoon. A cheering crowd would be
welcomed by the Jays.
Every team that the Jays have faced this year started
with one prime advantage, that of having scholarships
available to ace football players. As is known to all, Hopkins does not offer athletic scholarships as such, since according to Hopkins policy participation of true amateurs
is more important than victory. Also Hopkins tends to
emphasize intramural activities for the sake of participation.

Scott describes as "a hard runner that carries his 195 pounds

fullback posiiton. Jim Anthony
and Dick McCarty are pushing

him to learn the fullback duties,

Lanzi and Mike Yarus.
Bob Brennan, whom Scott calls
a good pass receiver and Bob

Harrington head' the ends at

impressive, especially on defense." Grim is a converted tackle.

Donald Dietz, Peter Tribulski,
Skip Tankersley, and Glenn
Bevans complete the tackle contingent.

Coach Scott says, "John Corcoran, Francis Daley, Dick Martin, and Sam Willis seem to be

position, each of them showing
pretty good ability." Backing
them are Vic Dates, Ken Malkus,
Paul Bridge, and Bill Grotz.

Junior College eleven next Friday, the Jay Frosh will face
Franklin and Marshall, Dickenson and Western Maryland on
successive Fridays.

shown enthusiasm, according to

postponement of fraternity golf
and tennis tournaments until the
Spring. Independent football begins today, while the deadline for
the first round independent golf
pairings is tomorrow.
